Best_Practice_Description: Always seek peer review, focusing on readability and maintainability (not just functionality).
Commit code frequently, focusing on a single, isolated change per commit to simplify debugging.
Maintain minimum 80% unit test coverage for new functionality to catch bugs early.
Treat all external input as untrusted; implement rigorous input sanitation and validation at boundaries.
Document all model training parameters, dataset versions, and random seeds (e.g., use MLflow or DVC).
Establish clear data quality checks before modeling, ensuring consistency and completeness.
Regularly assess model predictions across different demographic groups for bias and fairness.
Implement monitoring dashboards to track model drift and prediction latency in production.
Conduct quarterly reviews of key policies (e.g., WFH, PTO) to ensure compliance with local labor laws.
Treat all employee concerns confidentially and use active listening to understand underlying issues.
Use structured interview guides and consistent evaluation criteria to mitigate interviewer bias.
Facilitate regular 1-on-1 feedback sessions focused on development goals, not just performance.
Validate every financial model and report output against source data three times before distribution.
Clearly label and document all key assumptions used in financial projections and sensitivity analysis.
Minimize manual data entry; use tools like Python/VBA or Power Query for report generation.
Handle sensitive financial data (e.g., payroll, M&A) only on secure, encrypted systems.
Use scoring methods (Must Have, Should Have, etc.) to ensure the highest value items are always at the top of the backlog.
Maintain a single, accessible source of truth for the product roadmap and communicate changes immediately.
Shield the development team from external disruption during the sprint to maintain focus and velocity.
Spend at least 10% of time directly engaging with users/customers to gather qualitative feedback.
Manage all cloud resources via code (e.g., Terraform), enabling rapid deployment and rollback.
Automate everything from testing and builds to deployments and environment provisioning.
Define clear Service Level Objectives (SLOs) and configure alerts before issues impact users.
Test system resilience by simulating failures (e.g., turning off services) in staging environments.
Develop and continuously refine detailed customer personas to ensure all campaigns are relevant.
Implement robust tracking (UTMs, GTM) to accurately attribute all marketing spend to revenue generation.
Ensure all public-facing content strictly adheres to the company's brand voice, visual, and style guidelines.
Run simultaneous A/B tests on landing pages, emails, and ads to optimize conversion rates.
Spend 80% of initial calls asking questions to understand the client's pain points before pitching solutions.
Maintain a clean and accurate CRM (Salesforce/HubSpot) with clear next steps for every active opportunity.
Never over-promise product features; focus on real value and long-term customer relationships.
Establish automated, personalized follow-up sequences for leads that go cold.
Do not just document requested features; challenge stakeholders to find the underlying business need.
Write requirements (User Stories) using clear, non-technical language that is easily understood by both developers and business users.
Establish a formal change request process to evaluate and approve any deviation from the agreed scope.
Use visual tools (BPMN, flowcharts) to illustrate complex processes and data flows instead of lengthy text descriptions.
Define the project scope baseline early and strictly control changes against that baseline.
Create and execute a plan detailing who needs what information, when, and how (e.g., weekly status reports, daily standups).
Maintain a live register of risks, proactively monitoring top threats and executing mitigation plans before they become issues.
Build a realistic timeline using critical path analysis and include a management reserve for unforeseen delays.
Map test cases directly back to original user stories or requirements to ensure 100% coverage.
A defect must contain clear steps to reproduce, actual vs. expected results, and environment details.
Write automation scripts that are easy to update when the UI changes, avoiding brittle XPath locators.
Participate in design and requirement reviews before development starts to catch quality issues at the source.
Base all major design decisions on insights gathered from quantitative data or direct user testing.
Ensure all designs meet minimum WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) standards for color contrast, alt text, and keyboard navigation.
Maintain and use a centralized design system (e.g., Figma library) to ensure consistency across products.
Provide developers with clear specifications, spacing, and interactive prototypes for seamless implementation.
